evidence.dc:description: Western blot analysis using patient muscle biopsy showed predominance MyHC I (slow/beta-cardiac MyHC) and only full length MyHC I.

dc:source.dc:abstract: Myosin constitutes the major part of the thick filaments in the contractile apparatus of striated muscle. MYH7 encodes the slow/beta-cardiac myosin heavy chain (MyHC), which is the main MyHC isoform in slow, oxidative, type 1 muscle fibers of skeletal muscle. It is also the major MyHC isoform of cardiac ventricles. Numerous missense mutations in the globular head of slow/beta-cardiac MyHC are associated with familial hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. We identified a missense mutation, Arg1845Trp, in the rod region of slow/beta-cardiac MyHC in patients with a skeletal myopathy from two different families. The myopathy was characterized by muscle weakness and wasting with onset in childhood and slow progression, but no overt cardiomyopathy. Slow, oxidative, type 1 muscle fibers showed large inclusions consisting of slow/beta-cardiac MyHC. The features were similar to a previously described entity: hyaline body myopathy. Our findings indicate that the mutated residue of slow/beta-cardiac MyHC is essential for the assembly of thick filaments in skeletal muscle. We propose the term myosin storage myopathy for this disease.
dc:source.dc:creator: Tajsharghi H
dc:source.dc:title: Myosin storage myopathy associated with a heterozygous missense mutation in MYH7.

evidence.rdfs:label: SDS-page and WB

evidence.dc:description: The assembly of muscle filaments is a multi-step process that involves both the proper folding of α-helices into coiled-coils, and the assembly of these coiled-coils, in proper register, into filaments. Their findings indicate that defects in either one of these steps can result in improper filament formation leading to disease.

dc:source.dc:abstract: Myosin storage myopathy (MSM) is a congenital myopathy characterized by the presence of subsarcolemmal inclusions of myosin in the majority of type I muscle fibers, and has been linked to 4 mutations in the slow/cardiac muscle myosin, beta-MyHC (MYH7). Although the majority of the >230 disease causing mutations in MYH7 are located in the globular head region of the molecule, those responsible for MSM are part of a subset of MYH7 mutations that are located in the alpha-helical coiled-coil tail. Mutations in the myosin head are thought to affect the ATPase and actin-binding properties of the molecule. To date, however, there are no reports of the molecular mechanism of pathogenesis for mutations in the rod region of muscle myosins. Here, we present analysis of 4 mutations responsible for MSM: L1793P, R1845W, E1886K, and H1901L. We show that each MSM mutation has a different molecular phenotype, suggesting that there are multiple mechanisms by which MSM can be caused. These mechanisms range from thermodynamic and functional irregularities of individual proteins (L1793P), to varying defects in the assembly and stability of filaments formed from the proteins (R1845W, E1886K, and H1901L). In addition to furthering our understanding of MSM, these observations provide the first insight into how mutations affect the rod region of muscle myosins, and provide a framework for future studies of disease-causing mutations in this region of the molecule.
dc:source.dc:creator: Armel TZ
dc:source.dc:title: Mutations in the beta-myosin rod cause myosin storage myopathy via multiple mechanisms.

evidence.rdfs:label: MSM rod region mutations

evidence.dc:description: Both A1603P and K1617del mutations affected filament formation in vitro and also affect the localization of myosin into the muscle sarcomere in cultured skeletal muscle myotubes.

dc:source.dc:abstract: Over 20 mutations in β-cardiac myosin heavy chain (β-MHC), expressed in cardiac and slow muscle fibers, cause Laing early-onset distal myopathy (MPD-1), a skeletal muscle myopathy. Most of these mutations are in the coiled-coil tail and commonly involve a mutation to a proline or a single-residue deletion, both of which are predicted to strongly affect the secondary structure of the coiled coil. To test this, we characterized the effects of two MPD-1 causing mutations: A1603P and K1617del in vitro and in cells. Both mutations affected secondary structure, decreasing the helical content of 15 heptad and light meromyosin constructs. Both mutations also severely disrupted the ability of glutathione S-transferase-light meromyosin fusion proteins to form minifilaments in vitro, as demonstrated by negative stain electron microscopy. Mutant eGFP-tagged β-MHC accumulated abnormally into the M-line of sarcomeres in cultured skeletal muscle myotubes. Incorporation of eGFP-tagged β-MHC into sarcomeres in adult rat cardiomyocytes was reduced. Molecular dynamics simulations using a composite structure of part of the coiled coil demonstrated that both mutations affected the structure, with the mutation to proline (A1603P) having a smaller effect compared to K1617del. Taken together, it seems likely that the MPD-1 mutations destabilize the coiled coil, resulting in aberrant myosin packing in thick filaments in muscle sarcomeres, providing a potential mechanism for the disease.
dc:source.dc:creator: Parker F
dc:source.dc:title: A1603P and K1617del, Mutations in β-Cardiac Myosin Heavy Chain that Cause Laing Early-Onset Distal Myopathy, Affect Secondary Structure and Filament Formation In Vitro and In Vivo.

evidence.rdfs:label: A1603P and K1617del in Vitro and in Vivo

evidence.dc:description: In Drosophila, the Abba/Thin protein has a fundamental role in maintaining myofibril bundling and sarcomeric integrity during muscle development and usage. The phenotypes described for patients with mutations in TRIM/RBCC family members resemble those caused by Abba/Thin deficiency in flies, including reduced muscle function, myofiber fragmentation, and subsarcolemmal accumulation of myosin. Abba overexpression fully suppressed the phenotypic effects of heterozygous MhcK1728del, including reduced jump ability, lack of flight ability, and the myopathy of IFMs
evidence.rdfs:label: Drosophila overexpression Abba/Thin

evidence.dc:description: The rescue assay doesn't directly involve in MYH7 gene and mutation. Instead, it works through over-expression of a MyHCs protein degradation regulator Abba/Thin.

Overexpression of Abba can restore muscle morphology in flies with overexpressing eMhc R1844W mutation. Although some muscle dysfunction was enhanced, lack of flight ability was, however, not rescued by overexpression of Abba possibly due to a dominant antimorphic feature of embryonic Mhc.

dc:source.dc:abstract: Myosin is vital for body movement and heart contractility. Mutations in
dc:source.dc:creator: Dahl-Halvarsson M
dc:source.dc:title: Impaired muscle morphology in a

evidence.rdfs:label: Drosophila model - R1845W rescue

evidence.dc:description: The model system doesn't involve in gene disruption in MYH7 homolog, instead an overexpression of mutation R1844W. The rescue doesn't directly target MYH7 gene

Drosophilamodels are the first to recapitulate the human MSM phenotype with ultrastructural inclusions, suggesting that the diminished ability of the mutant myosin to form stable thick filaments contributes to the dystrophic phenotype observed in affected individuals.

dc:source.dc:abstract: Myosin storage myopathy (MSM) is a congenital skeletal muscle disorder caused by missense mutations in the β-cardiac/slow skeletal muscle myosin heavy chain rod. It is characterized by subsarcolemmal accumulations of myosin that have a hyaline appearance. MSM mutations map near or within the assembly competence domain known to be crucial for thick filament formation. Drosophila MSM models were generated for comprehensive physiological, structural, and biochemical assessment of the mutations' consequences on muscle and myosin structure and function. L1793P, R1845W, and E1883K MSM mutant myosins were expressed in an indirect flight (IFM) and jump muscle myosin null background to study the effects of these variants without confounding influences from wild-type myosin. Mutant animals displayed highly compromised jump and flight ability, disrupted muscle proteostasis, and severely perturbed IFM structure. Electron microscopy revealed myofibrillar disarray and degeneration with hyaline-like inclusions. In vitro assembly assays demonstrated a decreased ability of mutant myosin to polymerize, with L1793P filaments exhibiting shorter lengths. In addition, limited proteolysis experiments showed a reduced stability of L1793P and E1883K filaments. We conclude that the disrupted hydropathy or charge of residues in the heptad repeat of the mutant myosin rods likely alters interactions that stabilize coiled-coil dimers and thick filaments, causing disruption in ordered myofibrillogenesis and/or myofibrillar integrity, and the consequent myosin aggregation. Our Drosophila models are the first to recapitulate the human MSM phenotype with ultrastructural inclusions, suggesting that the diminished ability of the mutant myosin to form stable thick filaments contributes to the dystrophic phenotype observed in afflicted subjects.
dc:source.dc:creator: Viswanathan MC
dc:source.dc:title: Myosin storage myopathy mutations yield defective myosin filament assembly in vitro and disrupted myofibrillar structure and function in vivo.

evidence.rdfs:label: Drosophila MSM cell culture model

evidence.dc:description: The heterozygous MhcK1728del Drosophila muscle revealed large areas of sarcomeric disorganization with Z-disk streaming and extensions, reminiscent of the core and mini core-like lesions observed in muscle biopsies from patients carrying the heterozygous K1729del mutation. An increased severity of the morphological changes was observed with age, supporting progressive myopathy. The associated defects in sarcomere structure and myofibril damage resemble those observed in Laing distal myopathy. Larvae homozygous for MhcK1728del also display structural and functional changes in the heart muscle, which found in some patients with cardiac involvement.
evidence.rdfs:label: Drosophila cell culture model of MM K1729del

evidence.dc:description: Myosin storage myopathy is a protein aggregate myopathy associated with the characteristic subsarcolemmal accumulation of myosin heavy chain in muscle fibers. R1845W and H1901L mutants were prone to formation of myosin aggregates without assembly into striated sarcomeric thick filaments in cultured muscle cells.

dc:source.dc:abstract: Myosin storage myopathy is a protein aggregate myopathy associated with the characteristic subsarcolemmal accumulation of myosin heavy chain in muscle fibers. Despite similar histological findings, the clinical severity and age of onset are highly variable, ranging from no weakness to severe impairment of ambulation, and usually childhood-onset to onset later in life. Mutations located in the distal end of the tail of slow/ß-cardiac myosin heavy chain are associated with myosin storage myopathy. Four missense mutations (L1793P, R1845W, E1883K and H1901L), two of which have been reported in several unrelated families, are located within or closed to the assembly competence domain. This location is critical for the proper assembly of sarcomeric myosin rod filaments. To assess the mechanisms leading to protein aggregation in myosin storage myopathy and to evaluate the impact of these mutations on myosin assembly and muscle function, we expressed mutated myosin proteins in cultured human muscle cells and in the nematode Caenorhabditis elegans. While L1793P mutant myosin protein efficiently incorporated into the sarcomeric thick filaments, R1845W and H1901L mutants were prone to formation of myosin aggregates without assembly into striated sarcomeric thick filaments in cultured muscle cells. In C. elegans, mutant alleles of the myosin heavy chain gene unc-54 corresponding to R1845W, E1883K and H1901L, were as effective as the wild-type myosin gene in rescuing the null mutant worms, indicating that they retain functionality. Taken together, our results suggest that the basis for the pathogenic effect of the R1845W and H1901L mutations are primarily structural rather than functional. Further analyses are needed to identify the primary trigger for the histological changes seen in muscle biopsies of patients with L1793P and E1883K mutations.
dc:source.dc:creator: Dahl-Halvarsson M
dc:source.dc:title: Myosin Storage Myopathy in C. elegans and Human Cultured Muscle Cells.

evidence.rdfs:label: Cultured HM myoblast

dc:source.dc:abstract: Myosin heavy chain 7 (MYH7)-related myopathies are emerging as an important group of muscle diseases of childhood and adulthood, with variable clinical and histopathological expression depending on the type and location of the mutation. Mutations in the head and neck domains are a well-established cause of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy whereas mutation in the distal regions have been associated with a range of skeletal myopathies with or without cardiac involvement, including Laing distal myopathy and Myosin storage myopathy. Recently the spectrum of clinical phenotypes associated with mutations in MYH7 has increased, blurring this scheme and adding further phenotypes to the list. A broader disease spectrum could lead to misdiagnosis of different congenital myopathies, neurogenic atrophy and other neuromuscular conditions.
dc:source.dc:creator: Fiorillo C
dc:source.dc:title: MYH7-related myopathies: clinical, histopathological and imaging findings in a cohort of Italian patients.

evidence.dc:description: The A1603P variant has no pop data in gnomAD with damaging in-silico predictors by Provean (Score -2.7). There are multiple published nearby DM missense variants in HGMD. Muscle biopsy showed marked uniformity of fibre type and presence of diffuse mini-cores.The variant was also reported in other affected individuals by 3 other papers (PMID24664454, PMID29624713, PMID29660325).

evidence.phenotypeFreeText: fatty change in both anterior tibial muscles,vastusintermedius, vastus medialis and biceps femoris

dc:source.dc:abstract: The mutations of MYH7 (slow skeletal/β-cardiac myosin heavy chain) are commonly found in familial hypertrophic/dilated cardiomyopathy, and also can cause Laing early-onset distal myopathy (LDM), myosin storage myopathy (MSM), and congenital myopathy with fiber-type disproportion (CFTD). Here we report two cases whose diagnosis was hereditary myopathy according to clinical feature and muscle pathology analysis. High-throughput genomic sequencing (next generation sequencing) was performed to validate the diagnosis. Two MYH7 mutations, p.R1845W and p.E1687del, were identified. p.R1845W was found in a male patient showing weakness of both terminal lower legs without foot drop. Muscle pathology stainings characteristically showed the hyaline body in the intracytoplasmic location. The novel mutation p.E1687del was found in a family with seven patients. The proband showed foot drop, scoliosis, and winged scapula, while his mother only showed mild foot drop and winged scapula. Muscle pathology analysis showed congenital centronucleus myopathy. Both cases only showed muscular disorder and had no cardiomyopathy. This study, for the first time, reports the MYH7 mutations associated with centronucleus myopathy.
dc:source.dc:creator: Li N
dc:source.dc:title: MYH7 mutation associated with two phenotypes of myopathy.

evidence.rdfs:label: Patient 2

evidence.dc:description: The c.5059-5061delGAG variant occurs within a coiled coil region of the protein that is conserved across species and was not observed in gnomAD population database. Muscle biopsy showed non-specific myopathic changes with no signs of dystrophic or inflammatory changes;numerous rounded atrophic muscle fibers, isolated or grouped, were observed. Type I fiber predominance was noted and most atrophic fibers were type I. A tendency of fiber-type grouping was noted, without sarcoplasmic inclusions, cores,or minicores. In the NADH section, there were abnormalitiesin myofibril organization, such as eddy-like/Wipe pattern/myofibrillar netting disorders

dc:source.dc:abstract: Human skeletal muscles express three major myosin heavy chain (MyHC) isoforms: MyHCIIx (MYH1) in fast type 2B muscle fibers, MyHCIIa (MYH2) in fast type 2A fibers and MyHCI/β-cardiac MyHC (MYH7) in slow type I skeletal fibers and cardiac ventricles. In line with its expression pattern, MYH7 mutations have been reported in association with hypertrophic or dilated cardiomyopathy, skeletal myopathies or a combination of both. We analyzed the clinical and molecular phenotype of two unrelated families of Jewish Moroccan ancestry that presented with apparently autosomal dominant inheritance of progressive Laing-like distal myopathy with non-specific myopathic changes, but uncommon marked contractures and wasting of the neck extensors.
dc:source.dc:creator: Feinstein-Linial M
dc:source.dc:title: Two novel MYH7 proline substitutions cause Laing Distal Myopathy-like phenotypes with variable expressivity and neck extensor contracture.

evidence.dc:description: The R1434P variant is absent in gnomAD and found in 5 affected individuals in this family. Muscle biopsy done at the age of 50 years showed remarkable variability in fiber size with numerous internal nuclei and most of the fibers were Type 2. In vitro expression of the mutant in COS-7 cells demonstrated that R1434P impair myosin self-assembly properties and have dominant negative activity.

evidence.detectionMethod: PCR amplification of exons 30 to 40 followed by Sanger sequencing was performed.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Loss of neck control, wheelchair dependant by 15 yrs

dc:source.dc:abstract: Laing early onset distal myopathy and myosin storage myopathy are caused by mutations of slow skeletal/β-cardiac myosin heavy chain encoded by the gene MYH7, as is a common form of familial hypertrophic/dilated cardiomyopathy. The mechanisms by which different phenotypes are produced by mutations in MYH7, even in the same region of the gene, are not known. To explore the clinical spectrum and pathobiology, we screened the MYH7 gene in 88 patients from 21 previously unpublished families presenting with distal or generalized skeletal muscle weakness, with or without cardiac involvement. Twelve novel mutations have been identified in thirteen families. In one of these families, the father of the proband was found to be a mosaic for the MYH7 mutation. In eight cases, de novo mutation appeared to have occurred, which was proven in four. The presenting complaint was footdrop, sometimes leading to delayed walking or tripping, in members of 17 families (81%), with other presentations including cardiomyopathy in infancy, generalized floppiness, and scoliosis. Cardiac involvement as well as skeletal muscle weakness was identified in nine of 21 families. Spinal involvement such as scoliosis or rigidity was identified in 12 (57%). This report widens the clinical and pathological phenotypes, and the genetics of MYH7 mutations leading to skeletal muscle diseases.
dc:source.dc:creator: Lamont PJ
dc:source.dc:title: Novel mutations widen the phenotypic spectrum of slow skeletal/β-cardiac myosin (MYH7) distal myopathy.

evidence.rdfs:label: Family 6-III3

evidence.dc:description: The R1608P variant is absent in gnomAD population database and has damaging in-silico predictors. The grandfather of the proband is mosaic with mild muscle weakness.  Haplotyping confirmed the parents in this paper. Muscle biopsy showed Atrophic type 1 fibres with increased fibre size variability. Fibre grouping was present. Some cores and mutiminicore suggested myopathy. No functional studies.

evidence.detectionMethod: PCR amplification and sequencing of all 40 MYH7 exons

dc:source.dc:abstract: We previously linked Laing-type early-onset autosomal dominant distal myopathy (MPD1) to a 22-cM region of chromosome 14. One candidate gene in the region, MYH7, which is mutated in cardiomyopathy and myosin storage myopathy, codes for the myosin heavy chain of type I skeletal muscle fibers and cardiac ventricles. We have identified five novel heterozygous mutations--Arg1500Pro, Lys1617del, Ala1663Pro, Leu1706Pro, and Lys1729del in exons 32, 34, 35, and 36 of MYH7--in six families with early-onset distal myopathy. All five mutations are predicted, by in silico analysis, to locally disrupt the ability of the myosin tail to form the coiled coil, which is its normal structure. These findings demonstrate that heterozygous mutations toward the 3' end of MYH7 cause Laing-type early-onset distal myopathy. MYH7 is the fourth distal-myopathy gene to have been identified.
dc:source.dc:creator: Meredith C
dc:source.dc:title: Mutations in the slow skeletal muscle fiber myosin heavy chain gene (MYH7) cause laing early-onset distal myopathy (MPD1).

evidence.rdfs:label: Family 6

evidence.dc:description: The R1500P is absent in gnomAD. It was identified as de novo in this proband with confirmed maternity and paternity. Muscle biopsy showed  atrophy of the type I fibers. In vitro functional assays including in vitro protein expression of LMM and biochemical and biophysical characterizations showed the R1500P causes a decrease in thermodynamic stability, affect filament assembly, and decrease in filament stability

evidence.detectionMethod: The case directly targeted the Sanger sequencing of the coding regions of MYH7.
evidence.rdfs:label: Pt 9

evidence.dc:description: This variant p.Glu1801Lys is absent in gnomAD and damaging predictors by Provean.  It has been published multiple times (PMID24503780, 25576864, 24664454,19477645,27532257,28606303,28855170 and 31514951). One ClinVar entry (SCV000564459.4) reported de novo in two probands with dilated cardiomyopathy. Muscle biopsy performed at the age of 43 yrs revealed two different fibers: hypotrophic and rounded type I fibers and normal type 2 fibers. No mutation were found in DES, LMNA, ACTA1 and  ITGA7. Immunofluorescence (IF) showed normal expression of dystrophin, sarcoglycans, caveolin-3, dysferlin and merosin

evidence.detectionMethod: No detailed info about sequencing method. Assumed Sanger sequencing based on paper.

dc:source.dc:abstract: MYH7 gene mutations are related to a heterogeneous group of skeletal and cardiac myopathies.
dc:source.dc:creator: Dabaj I
dc:source.dc:title: Clinical and imaging hallmarks of the MYH7-related myopathy with severe axial involvement.

evidence.rdfs:label: P2

evidence.dc:description: This c.4814G>C (p.Thr1605Arg) missense variant is absent in gnomAD. It was inherited from mosaic father who presented with foot drop and distal lower limb weakness onset at 7 yrs old. Muscle biopsy using biceps brachii muscle performed at 10 yrs old showed type 2 fiber uniformity.

The c.4309G>C (p.A1437P) variant is absent in gnomAD.  Muscle biopsy of patient 4 in family B, demonstrated well preserved general structure, with random variability in fiber sizes with no atrophic fibers and most of the fibers were Type 2. In vitro expression of the mutant in COS-7 cells demonstrated that A1437P impair myosin self-assembly properties and have dominant negative activity.

c.5655+1 G>A variant is absent in gnomAD. Another same position variant c.5655+1G>C reported in ClinVar as likely pathogenic (ID986378). Muscle biopsy shows predominance of type I fibers and increased connective tissue. RT-PCR of mRNA analyses in skeletal muscle confirmed an in-frame skipping of the exon 38 leading to an in-frame loss of 32 amino acids. De novo and no fam hx reported but parents not specifically stated to be unaffected.

This variant is first reported by Pajusalu S et al.,2016 (PMID26782017) as heterozygous de novo by WES trio in male with early onset muscular weakness and delayed motor development in infancy. No abnl cardiac findings by echo at 21months of age. Total RNA was extracted from patient muscle sample, demonstrated by PCR and sequencing to cause in-frame skipping of exon 38. Here the author reported in this female proband as de novo. PCR reactions, performed using cDNA synthesized from muscle total RNA of the patient, result into short fragment, because of an abnormal splicing. This variant is seen 0.0026% (3/113750 alleles) in European (Non-Finnish) in gnomAD.

evidence.detectionMethod: The entire MYH7 coding sequence was amplified in 6 overlapping amplicons followed by next generation sequencing by Ion Torrent sequencing platform. Sanger sequencing was used for confirmation. Haplotying was used to confirm paternity and maternity.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: pulmonary hypertension,required cardiac transplant at 3.5 yrs
evidence.rdfs:label: Family 20-II3

evidence.dc:description: The E1914K variant was absent in gnomAD population database with damaging in-silico predictors. It has been published in several other individuals with DCM (PMID24503780,28606303,22464770). Muscle biopsy showed congenital Fibre Type Disproportion with myosin accumulation. The mutation was proven to be de novo by showing both parents did not carry the mutation, and haplotyping confirmed they were the parents in this paper. Functional studies by Alamo L., 2017 et.al (PMID28606303) used human beta-cardiac myosin interacting-heads motif (IHM) quasi-atomic model to define interaction sites between adjacent myosin heads and associated partners, and then analyzed variants in HCM/DCM pts from Walsh et al. 2017 (PMID28855170). No functional studies performed in skeletal muscles.

evidence.detectionMethod: The entire MYH7 coding sequence was amplified in 6 overlapping amplicons followed by next generation sequencing by Ion Torrent sequencing platform. Sanger sequencing was used for confirmation. Haplotying was used to confirm paternity and maternity.
evidence.rdfs:label: Family 21-II1

evidence.dc:description: The mutation was proven to be de novo by showing both parents did not carry the mutation, and haplotyping confirmed they were the parents in this paper. The two de novo cases harboring this variant in this paper are unrelated although both from USA. No mention of biopsy was performed in this proband Family 21-II1. The two biopsies in Family20 indicated the diagnosis was "Congenital Fibre Type Disproportion with myosin accumulation”. The E1914K has also been reported in 6 other publications (PMID22464770, 28855170, 27532257,	27532257,29300372,30996762). And Alamo L., 2017 et.al (PMID28606303) Used human beta-cardiac myosin interacting-heads motif (IHM) quasi-atomic model to define interaction sites between adjacent myosin heads and associated partners, and then analyzed variants in HCM/DCM pts from Walsh et al. 2017 (PMID28855170).

evidence.detectionMethod: Exons  32–34  of  the MYH7gene  were  amplified  by  PCR.The amplified regions were sequenced forward and reverse using Sanger sequencing.
evidence.previousTestingDescription: The  Finnish  patient  was  examined  in  London  and  first suspected  to  have  the  more  common  distal  myopathy  in Finland, titinopathy tibial muscular dystrophy (TMD, MIM600334,  Udd  myopathy).  After  genetic  exclusion  of  theFinnish TMD C-terminal titin founder mutation, reevaluation  of  the  clinical  phenotype  suggested  recessive  distalnebulin myopathy, or Laing distal myosinopathy.

dc:source.dc:abstract: Laing early-onset distal myopathy is a rare autosomal dominant myopathy and caused by mutations in the MYH7 gene, encoding the slow beta myosin heavy chain. We report the first molecularly verified Laing distal myopathy in a French family caused by a novel p.Glu1508del mutation in the MYH7 gene. Interestingly, we identified the identical mutation in an unrelated Norwegian family and, as a de novo mutation, in one sporadic Finnish patient. Described in detail are the clinical and electrophysiological characteristics of 5 patients from the French family. The phenotype in the Finnish patient and the Norwegian patients is largely similar. This mutation causes a benign myopathy within the range of previously reported Laing myopathy phenotype variations. Onset of weakness in the tibialis anterior (TA) muscles occurred in early childhood in all patients. Finger extensor and neck flexor weakness together with Achilles tendon retractions were other frequent findings. The independent recurrence of the identical mutation without any founder background may reflect a mutational susceptibility of this residue, in accordance with some other MYH7 mutations previously reported. De novo mutations seem to be frequent in Laing distal myopathy. This is of clinical importance since a dominant family history is missing, which may confuse differential diagnostic efforts.
dc:source.dc:creator: Dubourg O
dc:source.dc:title: A novel MYH7 mutation occurring independently in French and Norwegian Laing distal myopathy families and de novo in one Finnish patient.

evidence.rdfs:label: Finnish patient

evidence.dc:description: E1508del reported as mutation in three unrelated families (French, Norwegian, Finnish) with Laing early-onset distal myopathy. In addition, 2 other large families described by Naddaf et al 2015 (PMID25695922), 1 family in Reis GF, 2015, (26094647), Belgian adult female (Van den Bergh PY, 2014, (PMID24710723) and 2 families (USA/Polish and Belgium) in Lamont PJ, 2014, (PMID24664454). Neither  of  the  parents  of  the  Finnish  patient  carried  the mutation explaining  the  lack  of  family  history  and confirming the de novo status, but no mention confirming paternity or maternity. Functional studies was not performed.

evidence.detectionMethod: WES was used to identify the variant and followed by Sanger confirmation.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: axial myopathy,neck flexion weakness, moderate weakness of hip extension and ankle dorsiflexion, and mild weakness of shoulder abduction, hip flexion and knee flexion/extension
evidence.previousTestingDescription: Sanger sequencing was normal for ACTA1, SEPN1, LMNA, TPM3, TPM2, TNNT1 and MYOZ2.

dc:source.dc:abstract: MYH7 mutations are an established cause of Laing distal myopathy, myosin storage myopathy, and cardiomyopathy, as well as additional myopathy subtypes. We report a novel MYH7 mutation (p.Leu1597Arg) that arose de novo in two unrelated probands. Proband 1 has a myopathy characterized by distal weakness and prominent contractures and histopathology typical of multi-minicore disease. Proband 2 has an axial myopathy and histopathology consistent with congenital fiber type disproportion. These cases highlight the broad spectrum of clinical and histological patterns associated with MYH7 mutations, and provide further evidence that MYH7 is likely responsible for a greater proportion of congenital myopathies than currently appreciated.
dc:source.dc:creator: Clarke NF
dc:source.dc:title: A novel mutation expands the genetic and clinical spectrum of MYH7-related myopathies.

evidence.rdfs:label: Proband 2

evidence.dc:description: This missense p.Leu1597Arg (c.4790T>G) is absent in gnomAD. It was identified in two unrelated proband as de novo in this paper and the current proband Pt2 has been studied using whole exom sequencing. A quadriceps muscle biopsy taken at age 13 years demonstrated congenital fiber type disproportion. There was type 1 fiber predominance (82%), marked type 1 hypotrophy and type 2 fiber hypertrophy. No further functional study was performed.

evidence.detectionMethod: Proband was sequenced by Exome sequencing followed by confirmation using Sanger sequencing. Parent and sibling's DNA was also tested for the variant by Sanger sequencing as well as by paternity and maternity confirmation by STR typing.

dc:source.dc:abstract: Mutations in the MYH7 gene are the source of an allelic series of diseases, including various cardiomyopathies and skeletal myopathies that usually manifest in adulthood. We observed a 1.5 y.o. male patient with congenital weaknesses of the axial muscles, "dropped head" syndrome, and dilated cardiomyopathy. The clinical evaluation included medical history, an echocardiogram, electromyography, and a histopathological study. The genetic evaluation included whole exome sequencing. Muscle biopsy samples from the proband were used for mRNA extraction. We revealed a novel genetic variant c.5655 + 5G > C in the MYH7 gene. The analysis of the cDNA showed an in-frame skipping of exon 38 (p.1854_1885del). This variant and two previously published mutations (c.5655G > A and c.5655 + 1G > A), also presumably leading to exon 38 skipping, were studied by expression analysis in the HEK293T cell line transfected with 4 plasmids containing the MYH7 minigene (wt, c.5655G > C, c.5655 + 1G > A and c.5655 + 5G > A). A quantitative difference in expression was shown for cell lines with each of the three mutant plasmids. All mutation carriers had a similar phenotype and included congenital axial myopathy and variable cardiac involvement. Prominent dropped head syndrome was mentioned in all patients. Early-onset axial myopathy with a dropped head syndrome is a distinct clinical entity within MYH7-related disorders. We suggest that mutations in the MYH7 gene affecting the C-terminal domain of beta-myosin heavy chain should also be considered as a possible cause in cases of early-onset myopathy with "dropped head" syndrome.
dc:source.dc:creator: Surikova Y
dc:source.dc:title: Common pathogenic mechanism in patients with dropped head syndrome caused by different mutations in the MYH7 gene.

evidence.rdfs:label: Pt1-boy

evidence.dc:description: This c.5655+5G>C is absent in gnomAD. Functional studies were performed to determine the effect of c.5655+5G>C on splicing. cDNA sequencing of muscle biopsy samples from proband and healthy father revealed in-frame skipping of in-frame exon 38 due to the c.5655+5G>C mutation. Similarly, RT-PCR of transcripts from WT and mutant MYH7 minigene constructs expressed in cell lines again showed exon 38 skipping due to c.5655+5G>C, confirming the splicing defect caused by this mutation

evidence.detectionMethod: PCR amplification of exon 30 to 40 followed by Sanger sequencing
evidence.rdfs:label: F12-II1

evidence.dc:description: The p.Lys1617del variant was absent in gnomAD population database. The deleted residue is conserved in evolution. This variant was seen in 5 families (Family 8-12) in this paper from different localities in the UK and the USA. Family 8 proband presented in infancy, seen in 9 people over 5 generations. Family 9 proband in current curation presented at 1yr, 6 affected over 3 generations. Family 10-12 have 1 affected each. And it has also been reported in >8 published MPD1 families including those identified through WES (Komlósi K, 2014, PMID24300783 and  Oda T, 2015, PMID27081534). In this proband, the mutation was proven to be de novo and haplotyping confirmed they were the parents. Muscle biopsy showed rounded atrophic and hypertrophic fibres. Firbre size is increased with marked type 1 predominance.

evidence.detectionMethod: PCR amplification of MYH7 coding regions followed by sanger sequencing. The mutaion was confirmed by digesting a MYH7 exon 37 PCR product.
evidence.rdfs:label: Pt2

evidence.dc:description: The R1845W found as de novo in the proband and has no family history. Functional studies was performed in 3 other publications including PMID19336582, 28973424, 28125727) including biochemical and biophysical analysis of secondary structure in vitro and fly models in vivo. This is also a recurrent variant reported in other publications (PMID17118657, 28877744,29170849)

evidence.detectionMethod: PCR amplification of exons 30 to 40 followed by Sanger sequencing was performed. Haplotyping was used to confirm paternity and maternity.
evidence.rdfs:label: F18-II1

evidence.dc:description: The L1793del variant was absent in gnomAD population database. The deleted amino acid Leu is conserved in evolution. Muscle biopsy showed a congenital fibre type disproportion (CFTD).  The mutation was proven to be de novo by showing both parents did not carry the mutation, and haplotyping confirmed they were the parents. No functional studies performed.

evidence.detectionMethod: DNA sequencing of the coding regions and splice sites of the MYBPC3, TNNI3, TNNT2, TPM1 and MYH7 genes was performed. No mention of confirmation method.

dc:source.dc:abstract: A 25-year-old woman had childhood-onset muscle weakness and dilated cardiomyopathy. She exhibited predominantly distal weakness with early toe walking. Dilated cardiomyopathy required cardiac transplantation at age 15 years. We identified a de-novo, heterozygous, missense mutation, c.2348G>C (p. Arg783Pro), in exon 21 of the MYH7 gene, which encodes slow skeletal muscle fiber/β-cardiac myosin heavy chain protein, that replaces a highly conserved arginine with a proline. This novel mutation that results in the unusual combined cardiac and skeletal muscle phenotype localizes to the essential light chain binding area, a region only previously shown to be mutated in hypertrophic cardiomyopathy.
dc:source.dc:creator: Homayoun H
dc:source.dc:title: Novel mutation in MYH7 gene associated with distal myopathy and cardiomyopathy.

evidence.rdfs:label: P-25F

evidence.dc:description: The R783P variant was absent in gnomAD population databases and has a damaging prediction by provean. The substitution is located on a highly conserved residue. There are many nearby missense variants published in HGMD. Absence of the variant in both parents indicate de novo arised but no identify testing mentioned.The biopsy of right biceps muscle showed type 1 fiber atrophy and predominance, with type1 to type 2 fiber ratio of 3:2, and abnormal variation in myofiber sizes, which is consistent with a diagnosis of congenital myopathy. Plasma amino acids, urine amino acids, urine organic acids, thyroid panel and immunoglobulin panel were normal and muscle testing for mitochondrial deletions and common point mutations was negative.

dc:description: MYH7 was first reported in relation to autosomal dominant myopathy including Laing distal myopathy in 1995 (Laing et al., PMID7847377), myosin storage myopathy in 2013 (Bohlega et al.,PMID14663035) and scapuloperoneal syndrome in 2007 ( Pegoraro et al.,PMID17336526). At least 50 variants have been reported in humans. Evidence supporting this gene-disease relationship includes case-level data, segregation data and experimental data. Variants in this gene have been reported in at least 17​ probands in ​8​​ publications (​PMID27387980, 24664454,21211974,21279644,14520662,27519903,15322983,30794915). Variants in this gene segregated with disease in 37​​ additional family members. More evidence is available in the literature, but the maximum score for genetic evidence (12 pts.) has been reached. The mechanism for disease is dominant negative (Sjoberg et al.,PMID10545598). Of note, this gene has also been implicated in cardiomyopathy without myopathy.These ​have been​​ assessed separately by Cardiomyopathy Expert Panel. This gene-disease association is supported by ​animal models, expression studies, ​​in vitro​​ functional assays. In summary, ​MYH7​​ is definitively associated with Autosomal dominant myopathy​​. This has been repeatedly demonstrated in both the research and clinical diagnostic settings, and has been upheld over time. Per criteria outlined by the ClinGen Lumping and Splitting Working Group, we found no difference for Laing distal myopathy, myosin storage myopathy and scapuloperoneal syndrome and other MYH7 related myopathies (ex. PMID23478172, PMID29624713) in molecular mechanism AND inheritance pattern AND phenotypic variability. Therefore, all of the disease entities have been lumped into one disease entity, ​MYH7-related skeletal myopathy.
